panels.description: Name of Ηost.
panels.title: Host name

panels.description: Server model.
panels.title: Server model

panels.description: Host product version.
panels.title: Version

panels.description: Build number.
panels.title: Build

panels.description: Boolean value which indicates if Host is in maintenance mode. The result 1 (true) designates maintenance mode.
panels.title: Host In Maintenance (Boolean value)

panels.description: Total count of Virtual Machines, regardless of power state.
panels.title: Total VMs

panels.description: Uptime of Ηost.
panels.title: Host uptime

panels.description: Host connection state (connected / disconnected / notResponding).
panels.title: Host connection state

panels.description: Host power use in Watt.
panels.title: Power watt

panels.description: Host electric current value in Ampere.
panels.title: Electric Current

panels.description: Host electric Voltage value in Volt.
panels.title: Electric Voltage

panels.description: VMWare Fan temperature in centigrade.
panels.title: Host Fan temperature

panels.description: CPU model.
panels.title: CPU Model

panels.description: Number of processors in the Host.
panels.title: CPUs

panels.description: Host CPU max availability in MHz.
panels.title: CPU Capacity

panels.description:
Usage: Actively used CPU of the host, as a percentage of the total available CPU. Active CPU is approximately equal to the ratio of the used CPU to the available CPU.

Demand: The amount of CPU resources a virtual machine would use if there were no CPU contention or CPU limit.
panels.title: Host CPU utilization

panels.description:
Ready: Time that the virtual machine was ready, but could not get scheduled to run on the physical CPU during last measurement interval. CPU ready time is dependent on the number of virtual machines on the host and their CPU loads.

Co-stop: Time the virtual machine is ready to run, but is unable to run due to co-scheduling constraints.

Swap wait: CPU time spent waiting for swap-in.

Idle: Total time that the CPU spent in an idle state.
panels.title: Host CPU time utilization

panels.description:
Time accounted to the virtual machine. If a system service runs on behalf of this virtual machine, the time spent by that service (represented by cpu.system) should be charged to this virtual machine. 
If not, the time spent (represented by cpu.overlap) should not be charged against this virtual machine.
panels.title: Host CPU time used

panels.description: Host maximum memory availability in Mbytes.
panels.title: Host memory capacity

panels.description: Memory usage as percentage of total configured or available memory.
panels.title: Host memory usage

panels.description:
Active: Amount of memory that is actively used, as estimated by VMkernel based on recently touched memory pages.

Sum of all active metrics for all powered-on virtual machines plus vSphere services (such as COS, vpxa) on the host.
panels.title: Host active memory

panels.description: Amount of memory swapped-in from Host cache.
panels.title: Memory Swap in

panels.description: Rate at which memory is being swapped from Host cache into active memory.
panels.title: Memory Swap in rate

panels.description: Amount of memory swapped-out to Host cache.
panels.title: Memory Swap out

panels.description: Rate at which memory is being swapped from active memory to Host cache.
panels.title: Memory Swap out rate

panels.description:
Balloning: Amount of memory allocated by the virtual machine memory control driver (vmmemctl), which is installed with VMware Tools. It is a VMware exclusive memory-management driver that controls ballooning.

The sum of all vmmemctl values for all powered-on virtual machines, plus vSphere services on the host. If the balloon target value is greater than the balloon value, the VMkernel inflates the balloon, causing more virtual machine memory to be reclaimed. If the balloon target value is less than the balloon value, the VMkernel deflates the balloon, which allows the virtual machine to consume additional memory if needed.
panels.title: Balloning

panels.description: Percentage of time the virtual machine is waiting to access swapped or compressed memory.
panels.title: Average Host memory latency

panels.description: Datastore type (VMFS, NetworkFileSystem, NetworkFileSystem41, CIFS, VFAT, VSAN, VFFS).
panels.title: Datastore type

panels.description: Boolean value which indicates if Datastore is accessible. The result 1 (true) designates successful accessibility.
panels.title: Datastore accessibility status (boolean)

panels.description: Boolean value which indicates if Datastore is in maintenance mode. The result 1 (true) designates maintenance mode.
panels.title: Datastore maintenance mode (boolean)

panels.description: Number of Hosts using each Datastore.
panels.title: Hosts using datastore

panels.description: Number of Virtual Machines using each Datastore.
panels.title: VMs per datastore

panels.description: Datastore capacity size in bytes.
panels.title: Datastore capacity size

panels.description: Datastore free space size in bytes.
panels.title: Datastore free space

panels.description: Datastore uncommitted size in bytes.
panels.title: Datastore uncommited size

panels.description: Provizioned size: Amount of storage set aside for use by a datastore or a virtual machineFiles on the datastore and the virtual machine can expand to this size, but not beyond it. Available from datastore and virtual machine target entities.
panels.title: Datastore provisioned  size

panels.description: Datastore utilization (percentage).

targets.expr: ((vmware_datastore_capacity_size{job=~"$job", dc_name="$dc_name", ds_name=~"$datastore", ds_cluster=""} - vmware_datastore_freespace_size{job=~"$job", dc_name="$dc_name", ds_name=~"$datastore", ds_cluster=""}) / vmware_datastore_capacity_size{job=~"$job", dc_name="$dc_name", ds_name=~"$datastore", ds_cluster=""}) * 100

panels.title: Used Datastore

panels.description: Provisioned Datastore utilization (percentage).

targets.expr: ((vmware_datastore_provisoned_size{job=~"$job", dc_name="$dc_name", ds_name=~"$datastore", ds_cluster=""}) / vmware_datastore_capacity_size{job=~"$job", dc_name="$dc_name", ds_name=~"$datastore", ds_cluster=""}) * 100

panels.title: Provisioned Datastore space

panels.description: Disk Read and Write rate in bytes/sec.

targets.legendFormat: Disk Read and Write: Datacenter: {{ dc_name }}

panels.title: Disk R/W rate

panels.description:
Disk Read rate in  bytes/sec, thus rate at which data is read from each LUN on the host. 

Read rate = # blocksRead per second x blockSize.
panels.title: Disk Read rate

panels.description: Disk Read rate in  bytes/sec, thus average number of kilobytes written to disk each second during the collection interval.
panels.title: Disk Write rate

panels.description:
Data usage: Network utilization (combined transmit- and receive-rates) during the interval, thus the sum of data transmitted and received across all physical NIC instances connected to the host.

Data Rx: Average amount of data received per second.

Data Tx: Average amount of data transmitted per second.
panels.title: Host Network utilization

panels.description:
Errors Rx: Number of packets with errors received during the sampling interval.

Errors Tx: Number of packets with errors transmitted during the sampling interval.

Dropped Rx: Number of received packets dropped during the collection interval.

Dropped Tx: Number of transmitted packets dropped during the collection interval.
panels.title: Errors and dropped packets

panels.description:
VMWare sensor redundancy value (1=ok / 0=ko) labeled by sensor name from the host.

Architecting for redundancy means that if a VMware ESXi™ Server host fails,
neighboring hypervisors configured in the same VMware vSphere® cluster (a group of hosts) are able to
continue offering the virtualized layer without adversely impacting the VNFs.
panels.title: Redundancy (boolean)
